Example Sentence (Japanese): 彼は海外に住んでいます。
Example Sentence (English): He lives overseas.
Notes: Refers to foreign countries or abroad

Example Sentence (Japanese): 彼は営業部にいます。
Example Sentence (English): He is in the sales department.
Notes: Used to specify a department in a company

Example Sentence (Japanese): 事務仕事は大変です。
Example Sentence (English): Office work is tough.
Notes: Refers to administrative tasks

Example Sentence (Japanese): 手帳に予定を書きます。
Example Sentence (English): I write plans in my pocket notebook.
Notes: A small, portable notebook

Example Sentence (Japanese): ノートを買いました。
Example Sentence (English): I bought a notebook.
Notes: Commonly used for writing notes

Example Sentence (Japanese): 名刺を交換しました。
Example Sentence (English): I exchanged business cards.
Notes: Used for professional networking

Example Sentence (Japanese): 万年筆で手紙を書きます。
Example Sentence (English): I write letters with a fountain pen.
Notes: A type of pen used for formal writing

Example Sentence (Japanese): 鉛筆で絵を描きます。
Example Sentence (English): I draw pictures with a pencil.
Notes: Common tool for writing and drawing

Example Sentence (Japanese): ボールペンでメモを取ります。
Example Sentence (English): I take notes with a ballpoint pen.
Notes: A pen with a rolling ball tip

Example Sentence (Japanese): パソコンを使っています。
Example Sentence (English): I am using a personal computer.
Notes: Refers to a desktop or laptop computer

Example Sentence (Japanese): コンピューターが壊れました。
Example Sentence (English): The computer is broken.
Notes: Another term for a computer

Example Sentence (Japanese): 机の上に本があります。
Example Sentence (English): There is a book on the desk.
Example Sentence (Romaji): tsukue no ue ni hon ga arimasu.
Notes: Furniture used for working or studying

Example Sentence (Japanese): 椅子に座ってください。
Example Sentence (English): Please sit on the chair.
Notes: Furniture used for sitting

Example Sentence (Japanese): 時計は壁に掛けています。
Example Sentence (English): The clock is hanging on the wall.
Notes: Used to tell time

Example Sentence (Japanese): 壁に絵がかかっています。
Example Sentence (English): There is a picture hanging on the wall.
Notes: Visual art or illustration

Example Sentence (Japanese): 猫が寝ています。
Example Sentence (English): The cat is sleeping.
Notes: Common pet animal

Example Sentence (Japanese): 犬が散歩しています。
Example Sentence (English): The dog is taking a walk.
Notes: Common pet animal

Example Sentence (Japanese): 本は机の上にあります。
Example Sentence (English): The book is on the desk.
Example Sentence (Romaji): hon wa tsukue no ue ni arimasu.
Notes: Indicates position higher than something

Example Sentence (Japanese): ソファの下に猫がいます。
Example Sentence (English): The cat is under the sofa.
Example Sentence (Romaji): sofa no shita ni neko ga imasu.
Notes: Indicates position lower than something

Example Sentence (Japanese): 左に曲がってください。
Example Sentence (English): Please turn left.
Notes: Directional term for left

Example Sentence (Japanese): 右にあります。
Example Sentence (English): It is on the right.
Notes: Directional term for right

Example Sentence (Japanese): 隣の部屋にいます。
Example Sentence (English): I am in the next room.
Notes: Refers to an adjacent or neighboring place

Example Sentence (Japanese): 会議は午後 2 時からです。
Example Sentence (English): The meeting is from 2 p.m.
Example Sentence (Romaji): kaigi wa gogo ni-ji kara desu.
Notes: A gathering for discussion or work

Example Sentence (Japanese): 会議室は 3 階にあります。
Example Sentence (English): The meeting room is on the 3rd floor.
Notes: Room used for meetings

Example Sentence (Japanese): 午前 9 時に会議があります。
Example Sentence (English): There is a meeting at 9 a.m.
Example Sentence (Romaji): gozen ku-ji ni kaigi ga arimasu.
Notes: Refers to the time before noon

Example Sentence (Japanese): 午後 3 時に終わります。
Example Sentence (English): It ends at 3 p.m.
Notes: Refers to the time after noon

Example Sentence (Japanese): ここに座ってください。
Example Sentence (English): Please sit here.
Notes: Refers to the location of the speaker

Example Sentence (Japanese): そこに本があります。
Example Sentence (English): There is a book over there.
Notes: Refers to a location close to the listener

Example Sentence (Japanese): あそこに店があります。
Example Sentence (English): There is a store over there.
Notes: Refers to a location far from both speaker and listener

Example Sentence (Japanese): トイレはどこですか？
Example Sentence (English): Where is the toilet?
Notes: Used to ask about location

Example Sentence (Japanese): こちらが会議室です。
Example Sentence (English): This is the meeting room.
Notes: Polite way to refer to the current location

Example Sentence (Japanese): そちらの席に座ってください。
Example Sentence (English): Please sit in that seat.
Example Sentence (Romaji): sochira no seki ni suwatte kudasai.
Notes: Polite way to refer to a location near the listener

Example Sentence (Japanese): あちらが出口です。
Example Sentence (English): Over there is the exit.
Notes: Polite way to refer to a location far from both speaker and listener

Example Sentence (Japanese): どちらに行きますか？
Example Sentence (English): Which way should we go?
Notes: Polite way to ask for a location or direction

Example Sentence (Japanese): ここにペンがあります。
Example Sentence (English): There is a pen here.
Notes: Indicates the existence of something

Example Sentence (Japanese): 食堂でランチを食べます。
Example Sentence (English): I eat lunch at the cafeteria.
Notes: Refers to a place where meals are served

Example Sentence (Japanese): 私の部屋は 2 階にあります。
Example Sentence (English): My room is on the second floor.
Example Sentence (Romaji): watashi no heya wa ni-kai ni arimasu.
Notes: Refers to a personal or enclosed space

Example Sentence (Japanese): 外は寒いです。
Example Sentence (English): It is cold outside.
Notes: Refers to the external environment

Example Sentence (Japanese): 中に入ってください。
Example Sentence (English): Please come inside.
Notes: Refers to the interior of a space

Example Sentence (Japanese): 受付でチェックインしてください。
Example Sentence (English): Please check in at the reception desk.
Notes: Refers to a desk for visitor check-ins

Example Sentence (Japanese): トイレはどこですか？
Example Sentence (English): Where is the restroom?
Notes: Commonly used term for restroom

Example Sentence (Japanese): お手洗いは 1 階にあります。
Example Sentence (English): The restroom is on the first floor.
Notes: More formal term for restroom

Example Sentence (Japanese): 3 階に会議室があります。
Example Sentence (English): The meeting room is on the 3rd floor.
Notes: Indicates the floor level in a building

Example Sentence (Japanese): 階段を上がってください。
Example Sentence (English): Please go up the stairs.
Notes: Refers to a series of steps for ascending or descending

Example Sentence (Japanese): 何階にありますか？
Example Sentence (English): Which floor is it on?
Notes: Used to inquire about a floor level

Example Sentence (Japanese): エレベーターはどこですか？
Example Sentence (English): Where is the elevator?
Notes: Refers to a device for lifting between floors

Example Sentence (Japanese): 150 枚の資料があります。
Example Sentence (English): There are 150 sheets of materials.
Example Sentence (Romaji): hyaku gojuu-mai no shiryō ga arimasu.
Notes: Used for counting sheets, tickets, etc.

Example Sentence (Japanese): 自動販売機でジュースを買いました。
Example Sentence (English): I bought a drink from the vending machine.
Notes: Refers to a machine for selling products

Example Sentence (Japanese): 課長は会議に出席しています。
Example Sentence (English): The manager is attending the meeting.
Example Sentence (Romaji): kachō wa kaigi ni shusseki shiteimasu.
Notes: Refers to a middle management position

Example Sentence (Japanese): 部長は会議室にいます。
Example Sentence (English): The general manager is in the meeting room.
Notes: Refers to a senior management position

Example Sentence (Japanese): 社長は本社にいます。
Example Sentence (English): The company president is at the headquarters.
Notes: Refers to the top executive in a company

Example Sentence (Japanese): 彼の年収は 1 億円です。
Example Sentence (English): His annual income is 100 million yen.
Example Sentence (Romaji): kare no nenshu wa ichi-oku en desu.
Notes: Used for very large numbers, mainly in finance
